hedline.hl1: POSTINGS: At the Intersection of Routes 440 and 278; A Hilton for Staten Island

abstract.p: Hilton Garden Inn will rise next to Corporate Park of Staten Island in northwestern part of borough (S)

block.p: Ground has been broken for a new hotel, the Hilton Garden Inn, at 1100 South Avenue, near the intersection of Routes 440, the West Shore Expressway, and 278, the Staten Island Expressway. The hotel will include 150 guest rooms and 9,000 square feet of banquet space and is scheduled to open in July 2001.

The hotel, adjacent to the Corporate Park of Staten Island in the northwestern part of the borough, is aimed at the midprice traveler, with room rates ranging from $109 to $129 a night. It will be the first Hilton hotel on Staten Island.

Ground has been broken for a new hotel, the Hilton Garden Inn, at 1100 South Avenue, near the intersection of Routes 440, the West Shore Expressway, and 278, the Staten Island Expressway. The hotel will include 150 guest rooms and 9,000 square feet of banquet space and is scheduled to open in July 2001.

The hotel, adjacent to the Corporate Park of Staten Island in the northwestern part of the borough, is aimed at the midprice traveler, with room rates ranging from $109 to $129 a night. It will be the first Hilton hotel on Staten Island.

A distinguishing feature of the building will be a glass-walled pavilion with a 30-foot ceiling that will enclose the reception and public areas. It will include a retail market with a limited selection of microwavable and frozen foods, snacks and beverages. The structure will also include a lobby bar and a small restaurant serving breakfast and lunch.

There are to be three meeting rooms, a business center with copiers and fax machines and an exercise room with a whirlpool. Guest rooms will have electrical outlets and telephone jacks at desk height, and each room will have two telephones with two lines and voice mail. Desks will be equipped with a pullout shelf for a portable computer, and adjustable lighting, to make computer screens easier to read. The hotel is being developed by the Nicotra Group of Staten Island.
